title: Managing Difficult Stakeholders
description: Navigate resistance, disengagement, and conflict through negotiation, influence, and re-engagement strategies.
objectives: Apply negotiation strategies (Win-Win vs Win-Lose vs Withdraw) based on relationship importance
Distinguish when to escalate vs manage at project level
Use influence tactics for stakeholders where PM lacks formal authority
Recognize resistance patterns and apply appropriate responses
Re-engage disengaged stakeholders through empathy and reduced friction

screens.headline: 3 Difficult Stakeholders. 3 Different Problems. Wrong Strategy = Project Failure.

dialogue.text: Each requires a DIFFERENT strategy. Victor needs escalation + negotiation. Diana needs re-engagement. Roberto needs influence without authority. Get it wrong, and the project fails.

screens.learningHook: How do you manage stakeholders you can't control? Learn when to escalate, when to negotiate, when to influence without authority.

screens.title: Difficult Stakeholder Scenarios
screens.instructions: Select the appropriate strategy for each difficult stakeholder situation.

options.text: Comply with $80K demand to avoid conflict
Refuse and threaten legal action
Escalate to Elena (CFO) + seek Win-Win alternative ($15K code-compliant + safety audit)
Negotiate directly (offer $40K compromise)

feedback.correct: Perfect! ESCALATE when: beyond PM authority ($80K > $50K), possible corruption, organizational risk. Win-Win alternative addresses Victor's stated concern (safety) without the unreasonable cost.
feedback.incorrect: This situation requires ESCALATION. $80K exceeds Alex's authority, there's possible corruption, and permits are critical. Escalate to Elena while proposing a Win-Win alternative.

scenarios.title: Diana Chen - Disengaged Investor
description: Was initially supportive, attended all meetings
Need her approval for $500K funding release
Root cause: Her portfolio company failed—she's overwhelmed

options.text: Demand her attendance at next board meeting
Replace her with another investor
Acknowledge her challenges, offer condensed 15-min update, ask how Alex can support
Go around her to other investors for approval

feedback.correct: Excellent! RE-ENGAGEMENT requires empathy + reduced friction. Acknowledge her situation, make engagement easier, rebuild trust. Disengagement isn't always about your project.
feedback.incorrect: Diana is overwhelmed, not disinterested. Show empathy, reduce friction (15-min video vs 60-min meeting), ask how you can support her.

scenarios.title: Roberto Silva - Passive-Aggressive Resistance
description: Roberto reports to Carlos (GM), not Alex
Publicly agrees ('Yes, I'll order equipment by Friday')
Privately undermines ('forgets' to order, blames suppliers)
Root cause: Resents that HQ has PM authority over Mexico operations
Alex has NO FORMAL AUTHORITY over Roberto

questions.question: How should Alex influence Roberto without authority?

options.text: Escalate to Carlos to discipline Roberto
Publicly confront Roberto in next meeting
Build coalition (Carlos endorses Alex), use reciprocity (help Roberto), acknowledge his expertise
Bypass Roberto, work directly with his team

feedback.correct: Perfect! INFLUENCE WITHOUT AUTHORITY = Coalition + Reciprocity + Acknowledge Expertise. Address the ROOT CAUSE (resentment), not just symptoms (missed deadlines).
feedback.incorrect: You can't command respect—earn it. Build coalition support, help Roberto with HIS priorities, acknowledge his local expertise.

scenarios.title: Negotiation Strategy Selection
description: 4 different stakeholder conflicts requiring different strategies

questions.question: Match each conflict to the appropriate negotiation strategy:

items.label: Vendor price dispute (ongoing relationship)
items.match: Win-Win (negotiate reduced scope or extended terms)

items.label: One-time consultant ($20K for $5K work, no future need)
Developer wants transfer mid-project (relationship important)
items.match: Win-Win (stay until milestone, then transfer + recommendation)

items.label: Marketing wants feature outside scope (key stakeholder)
items.match: Win-Win (add to Phase 2 backlog or trade for other feature)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Win-Win for ongoing relationships. Win-Lose/Withdraw for one-time unreasonable demands where you have leverage.
feedback.incorrect: Default to Win-Win for important relationships. Use Win-Lose only when relationship doesn't matter and demand is unreasonable.

escalateWhen: Power imbalance (stakeholder power exceeds PM influence)
dontEscalateWhen: PM has authority and tools to resolve

strategies.name: Win-Win (Collaborate)
strategies.when: Ongoing relationship, both have legitimate interests

strategies.name: Win-Lose (Compete)
strategies.when: One-time, stakeholder unreasonable, PM has leverage

strategies.name: Withdraw (Avoid)
strategies.when: Not worth engaging, better alternatives exist

strategies.name: Lose-Lose
strategies.example: Cut quality to save cost, harming everyone

tactics.name: Coalition Building
tactics.detail: Get powerful stakeholders to endorse your role

tactics.name: Reciprocity
tactics.detail: Help them with THEIR priorities first

tactics.name: Reduce Friction
tactics.detail: Make engagement easier (15-min video vs 60-min meeting)

tactics.name: Rebuild Trust
tactics.detail: Ask how you can support their goals

correct.text: Alex escalated to me. $80K exceeds authority + possible corruption = executive decision. Our Win-Win ($15K + audit) addressed safety without paying the unreasonable demand. Victor backed down when he saw we weren't easy targets.

I acknowledged Diana's challenges with her portfolio company. Offered a 15-min video summary instead of 60-min meetings. She responded: 'Thank you for understanding. Let's do the 15-min update.' She's re-engaged.

Alex helped Roberto with his supplier issue, publicly acknowledged his local expertise. Roberto stopped the passive resistance. He said: 'Alex respects my knowledge. I'll support the project.' Reciprocity works.

screens.title: Vancouver Zoning Official
screens.context: Vancouver expansion faces a difficult stakeholder requiring escalation + negotiation.

scenario.title: Possible Corruption Case
details: City Zoning Official demands $50K 'consultation fee' for approval

options.text: Pay the $50K fee (relationship important)
ESCALATE to Elena (exceeds authority, possible corruption)
Threaten to report to ethics board
Ignore and proceed without permit

feedback.correct: Correct! ESCALATE: $50K exceeds $30K authority + possible corruption = executive decision required.
feedback.incorrect: $50K exceeds Alex's authority and suggests corruption. This must be escalated to Elena.

questions.question: What Win-Win alternative should Alex propose?

options.text: Standard $5K fee + expedited timeline (addresses speed concern)
Offer $25K (split the difference)
Threaten to report to ethics board
Accept delay without negotiating

feedback.correct: Perfect! Win-Win addresses the official's legitimate concern (speed) with expedited timeline while paying the standard ethical fee.
feedback.incorrect: Win-Win means addressing legitimate concerns ethically. Standard fee + expedited timeline addresses speed without paying suspicious fees.

screens.title: Difficult Stakeholder Mastery
screens.summary: Managing difficult stakeholders requires emotional intelligence and strategic frameworks—not just technical PM skills.
takeaways: Escalate when: Beyond authority, unreasonable/unethical, organizational risk, power imbalance
Negotiation: Win-Win for ongoing relationships, Win-Lose for one-time unreasonable demands
Influence without authority: Coalition, reciprocity, acknowledge expertise, persuasion
Re-engagement: Understand root cause, reduce friction, rebuild trust
Emotional intelligence matters: Empathy, active listening, understand context

artifacts.title: Difficult Stakeholder Playbook
artifacts.description: Escalation checklist, negotiation matrix, influence tactics

characterClosing.text: Victor needed escalation. Diana needed empathy. Roberto needed respect. Each difficult stakeholder has a different root cause—and a different solution. That's what separates good PMs from great ones.
